Description: Lower body sherd of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery dinos; white slip; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of animal frieze (from left, rump with added red of seated lion; legs and rump with red of second seated lion; foreleg, body with red and trace of wing of sphinx remaining), all to left; incised rising and full rosettes with red centres and red blobs as filling ornament; below, concentric brown bands; below, lotus flower and lotus bud pattern with red.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Manchester Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd belongs to the same vase as Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology NA107.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 318, no. 1403) (Incorrectly labelled III D.12)
Webster 1932-1933 / Greek Vases in the Manchester Museum (p. 2, pl. I, no. 3)
Walter-Karydi 1973 / Samische Gefässe des 6. Jahrhunderts vor Christi: Landschaftsstile ostgriechischer Gefässe (p. 138, no. 694)
Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 144, fig. 7)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0041) (phase 2)
